That Andy Knecht is a real, sure
enough pitcher and just the twirler
the Black and Blue team has needed
all season was demonstrated for the
second time when he pitched a wonderful game against the Mount St.
Mary's nine last Wednesday, holding the visitors to a single run, as
against nine made by Hopkins.
And Andy had wonderful support.
The whole tone of the team's
playing has been raised tremendously by the acquisition of a pitcher
who can pitch, and one could not
wish to see a better brand of ball
playing than has been pulled off
during the last two games. Mt. St.
Mary's was held to three hits during the entire game.
"
Hopkins started off with a rush,
netting three runs in the first inning. Grace, the first man up, was
passed; Hayter got to first on an
error and Captain Shad Sharretts
walked. With the bases full Knecht
came to the bat and, not content
with good pitching alone, knocked
one into the right garden, and all
three men came honie.

day, Richard M. Wood was elected
president of Student Council by a
small majority over Gilson Engel.
At the same time officers and delegates were elected to the A. A.
Board, who will take their places
next fall. The results were as follows:
President A. A. _Board—A. H.
Knecht.

Wm. Totterdale.

Edwards.

Senior Delegates—Eli Frank, J.
(.. Thompson, C. R. Sharretts, Jr.
Junior Delegates—T. M. Landy,
W. H. Somerville.
Sophomore Delegate—H. Barton.
Two amendments to the constitution of the General Athletic
Board were submitted and passed.
The first is, that the cross-country
team be constituted a. division of
the track team with its own captain, who shall be rated as a minor
sport captain; that the cross-country airard shall be as follows: A

South Atlantic or Middle States
Cross Country Championship or to
an individual winning first place in
these runs. A cHc shall be
awarded the qualifying members of
a cross-country team winning a
dual or' triangular cross-country

PROM TO OPEN SENIOR
WEEK ON JUNE 17
Exercises to Continue Until Twenty-first
When Degrees Will Be Conferred
At Lyric. Class Day on Gilman Hall Steps on Monday, June 20.

As the time for the closing exercises of the year draw near, the
committee in charge of "Senior
Week" is busy putting on the finishing touches. It has arranged a
very attractive program, which will
start with the "Senior Prom" on
the evening of June 17th, and will
continue through the week until
Tuesday the 21st, on which day the
conferring of degrees will take
place.

OMICRON DELTA KAPPA INITIATES NINE MEN

RUTGERS WINS NINTH MIDDLE ATLANTIC STATES

Include Six Undergraduates, Dr. Dunlap, Van Orman and Griswold.
Major Garey Speaks at Privite Initiation.

Hopkins Finishes Fifth. Close Finish in
the Mile Run. Edwards Wins
Half Mile.

Six active members from the student body, one from the faculty,
and two honorary members were
announced as elected to the Omicron Delta Kappa Society by Robert Graham Heiner, its retiring
president, at the assembly last week.
They are: Ralph Firestone Bowers, '21, organizer and director of
the Band and Orchestra, and director of the Musical Club;
Thomas Foy Hubbard, '21,_ art editor of both the Hullabaloo and the
Black and Blue Jay, treasurer of the
Senior Class, and member of the
Tau Beta . Pi Fraternity; Frederick Russell Calkins, '21, for three
years on the Football Team, one
year on the Lacrosse Team, one
year on the Track Team, secretary
of the Glee Club, and member of
the quartette in that organization,
and corresponding secretary of the
General Athletic Board; Henry
Douglas Cotton, '22, editor-in-chief
of the NEWS-LETTER; business manager of the Black and Blue Jay,
editor of the Daily Bulletin, secretary of the Junior Class, and undergraduate contributor to the Alumni
(Continued on page 7 col. 1)

TENNIS TEAM OPENS SEASON
WITH DEFEAT
Downed by Naval Academy Racqueters
5 to 1. Duffy Only Hopkins
Player to Win His Match.

The Tennis Team lost its first
match of the season to Navy last
Wednesday by a score of 5 to 1.
Wells, Rowland and Pickford were
all defeated in the singles competition, while Captain Duffy was the
only Hopkins racqueteer who was
able to score a victory over his
Midshipman opponent. In the doubles Pickford and Wells lost, 6-3,
6-1, while Duffy and Rowland were
defeated in a hard-contested match,
6-2, 7-5.
The matches were played on a
cold and windy day and the inclement weather had made practice for
the week previous impossible. Considering the fact that Navy always
turns out one of the, best teams in
the country, the team's showing was
far from bad, and with the aid of
a little good weather ought to be
iContinued on page 7 col. 2)

Johns Hopkins, in spite of the
fact that her squad was divided,
finished fifth in the ninth annual
Middle Atlantic- States collegiate
meet • Saturday, collecting 13 2
points., in competition with the best
athletes in the conference.
Rutgers, winner of the meet,
piled up 28 points, defeating Lafayette, her nearest rival, by 6
points.
Seven M. A. S. C. records were
broken, four in the field and three
!in the track events. The first
record to fall was the 100-yard
dash, in which Le Coney, of Lafayette, clipped- two-fifths of a second
off of the old record, which has
stood for six years, his time being
94-5 seconds.
The most thrilling race, from a
Hopkins point of view, was the
half-mile, wone by Edwards. Holding fourth position until the last
lap, he burst into a terrific sprint,
passing McPherson, of Lehigh;
Crawford, of Lafayette, and Stuart,
of Rutgers, who had set the pace.
The time, 1 minute 59 4-5 seconds,
was within 3-5 of a second of the
record. This was Hopkins only
first place.
Clark also performed admirably,
coming in a close second in the 100yard dash and third in the 220-yard
dash. Aaronson finished third in
the 220-yard low hurdles and tied
with Reinhartz, of Muhlenberg, for
fourth place in the pole vault.
Another exciting feature of the
day was the mile run, in which
Crawford, of Lafayette, and
Booth, of Delaware, tied for first.
Somerville came- in a safe third,
leaving the rest of the field some
distance back.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 17, 1921
THE HONOR SYSTEM

The Dean, in his short discussion
of the Honor System at the assembly last Thursday, brought several
facts to the fore that might be given serious attention by the students.
The most important of these without question is whether the doubts
expressed by members of the Faculty and students as to the practicability of the system are supported
by any real foundation. The Dean
himself and the Student Council
think otherwise and every Hopkins
man that has the real welfare of our
college at heart hopes that they are
right in their stand.
It certainly is to be deplored that
any suspicion of dishonesty should
be even thought of in an institution such as ours. The only way by
which talk of this character may
be stopped is to show the authors
of these stories that the condition
does not exist by holding the June
Examinations so that no shadow of
cheating can possibly be conjured
up by any person who is waiting to
grasp the vestige of an irregularity
to cry out the failure of the Honor
System.

The Debating Council, at a recent meeting, elected R.• Dorsey
Watkins, '22, president, and Lawrence B. Fenneman, '23,secretaryireasurer. Charles C. Marbury,
'22
.
; Adolphus D. Emmart, '22;
Parker C. Williams, '23, and J. E.
Mount, '24, were chosen to represent the senior, junior and sophomore classes in the Debating Council in 1921-'22.
The Council voted to award
Varsity Seals to R. Dorsey Watkins, Adolphus D. Emmart, Parker
C. Williams and Albert Dimond,
.C
the Hopkins debaters in the Triangular Debate with Washington
and Lee and the University of
North Carolina. These names will
be awarded to the Varsity Seal
Voting Council for final action.
The Council further decided that
Hopkins would insist upon the careful and judicial selection of judges
for future triangle debates. The
failure of the other universities to
select judges for their contests, as
prescribed by the general agreement, has worked disadvantageously
tc Johns Hopkins. According to
the existing agreement the judges
were to be. members of the faculty
of the university at which the debate is held. In the recent triangle
affair of April 30th, three members
of the board of judges at the University of North Carolina and only
one at Washington and Lee were
chosen according to the stipulations
of the agreement.
Incidentally the Hopkins debaters received the favorable decisions of all of these.

Hisler, of Drexel, won tremendous applause in the two-mile
run. Leading from the start, he
finished far ahead of his nearest
rival, Schmidt, of Bucknell. His
time, 9 minutes 45 seconds, broke
another record.
Betzmer, of -Delaware, in the
javelin throw, gave a wonderful exhibition of physical prowess, hurling for a distance of 172 feet 2
inches, breaking still another
record.
Despite the heavy rains of the
week, the paths were in. excellent
condition. The weather was ideal
and although the stands were but
sparsely filled for the opening of
the games, an enthusiastic crowd
witnessed the finals and the field
events.

the army, Miss Turner?"
"I don't remember exactly, but
I think Tubby had charge of the
war."
Report has it that Winnie Harden was arrested for poaching one
night last week out in the sticks
near Ten Hills, and that he had a
lamp and several boxes of matches
with him. The judge paid no attention to his excuse that he was
only curious to discover whether
rabbits slept on their right side or
on their back.
"What sort of a tree is that?"
queried a Chicago girl touring
California.
"Fig tree," replied her escort.
"My goodness, I thought the
leaves were larger!"

The hall will be artistically decorated with the University and class
colors. There will be special favors for all and the suitably engraved and neatly bound souvenir
cards. It is the committee's desire
to make this the best Senior Prom
ever held at Homewood. and from
all indications their desire will be
fulfilled.
On Saturday, the 18th, there will
probably be an Alumni Smoker to
the graduates at the Hopkins Club.
This has not as yet been fully decided upon.
Sunday morning, at the 11 o'clock
service at Grace and St. Peter's,
Dr. H. P. Almon Abbott will preach
the baccalaureate sermon. The students will march in wearing their
caps and gowns, headed by the
faculty similarly attired. There will
be about 400 seats reserved in the
front of the church for the friends
of the students and the faculty.
Class Day comes on Monday-, the
20th, at 3:30 P. M. . It will take
place on the main.steps of. Gilman
Hall. The program for the afternoon will be as follows: '
L Selection- .by Undergraduate
Band.
2. Address by Chairman C. I: T.
Gould.
3. Award of athletic honors by
Dr. Abercrombie.
4. Class statistics and awards, by
C. I. T. Gould.
5. Unveiling of Sigma Chi Beta
tablet to most popular men.
6. Address by Dr. Charles
Swarts, honorary president of the
class.
7. University songs by University Quartet.
8. Presentation of 0. D. K. Cup
by Joseph C. Thompson.
9. Address by K. R. Mulliken,
president of Class of 1921.

After the completion of these exercises an informal tea dance will
be held in the C. E. Hall. The Music will probably be furnished by
the Undergraduate Orchestra.
At nine o'clock the same evening
the Senior Banquet will be held.
The managements are in the hands
of E. R. Taylor and a committee.
Ralph F. Bowers has been chosen
toastmaster for the evening. Beside Bowers the speakers will be:
Dr. Charles Swartz, "The Class
of 1921."
E. S. Wood, "Athletics."
R. G. Heiner, "Student Activities."
K. R. Mulliken, "The University."
The "Senior Week" will come to
v close on Tuesday, June 21st. The
conferring of degrees will take
place at the Lyric at four o'clock.
All students are urged to be present and it is hoped that they will
also be present- at tlas§ day and
other such occasions as .they: are
for the entire student body as well
as the graduates.

AN OPEN LETTER TO THE JUNIOR
AND SOPHOMORE CLASSES'.

Gentlemen:
Every activity on the campus at
Homewood welcomes publicity for
Johns Hopkins—of the right kind.
But the wrong kind of publicity is
much worse than none at all—particularly the kind that spreads by
rumor and is exaggerated as it is
passed on.- Some such undesirable
publicity, persistent and widespread, has been produced by reports of the entertainment at the
recent class banquets of the junior
and the sophomore classes. An excess of zeal on .the part of paid entertainers apparently resulted in a
type of vaudeville out of place in a
gathering of college men and distasteful to practically all of the
guests. There is one sure way to
prevent a recurrence of this sort of
thing at future class dinners and
that is a return to the tradition of
former years—class dinners at
which there are no paid entertainers. If tired business men want .to
be cheered and soothed at their
gatherings by female dancers and
monologists imported from the Gayety Theater that is their affairs;
but college men, who are living the
intellectual life ought certainly to
have wit and good fellowship
enough to make such a recourse inadequate and unnecessary. Consequently, the Omicron Delta Kappa
Society speaking, it firmly believes,
for the best public opinion on the
campus, urges upon the classes concerned the adoption for next year
of a policy that will make impossible such criticism as has been going about recently.
A Co \I MITTEE OF THE 0. D. K.
ALL HONOR OR NO HONOR?
JOHNS HOPKINS.

We must have a system either
entirely with Or without honor. If
we have the first, the student should
be given no reason to believe that
there is any doubt of his honor.
The signing of pledge slips and the
occasional supervision by "watchmen" should be entirely done away
with. Both of these are blots on
our present system and are a constant remihder of a lurking distrust
on the part of our faculty.
A man should be free to takz.•
an exam in any room that he wishes.
One of the best proofs that I
have ever seen of the efficiency of
the system occurred last year. With
six other students of the same
course, all of them average-minded
members of the student body, I left
an examination room and took the
exam, in a cooler and quieter room
away from the distracting gazes of
some fifty classmates. I can honestly say that there was not even
the least hint of help given or received in the room during the entire examination.
In adopting.a 100 per cent. honor
system we are not experimenting;
we are using a system that has been
tried and found successful in hundreds of other institutions.
For my part I shall be happy to
see the time when Hopkins joins
this progressive group and leaves
behind the elementary school tacD. M.
tics now in use.

COURSE ON INTRODUCTION TO
COLLEGE WORK TO BE GIVEN
NEXT YEAR.

According to an announcement
made last week, a novel course is
to be established at the University
next year. •
The course, which is to be known
as "Introduction to College Work,"
will be an elective for freshmen and
will be limited to 25 students.
Dr. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, who is
responsible for the establishment of
the course, will supervise the instruction, with the assistance of instructors from several of the other
departments.
It is believed that this course,
which is regarded as unique in college curricula, will serve to better
fit the entering student for his coming work.

Among the subjects covered will
be methods of study, principles of
logical reasoning, elementary statistical methods, observation of
physical fact, how scientific theory
is built up and the ideals and aims
of science.

The Omicron Delta Kappa Fraternity was founded at Washington
and Lee University in 1914, and the
Beta Circle was instituted at this
university in 1916 Its membership comprises students who have
distinguished themselves in scholarship, athletics, social leadership, including conspicuous service to the
college; literary work, including
contests, and college journalism.
Only three per cent. of the undergraduate enrollment may be elected
in any one year.
The private initiation of these
men was held Thursday evening at
the Hopkins Club. The speakers on
this occasion were Major Enoch B.
Garey, commandant of the R. 0.

enough pitcher and just the twirler
the Black and Blue team has needed
all season was demonstrated for the
second time when he pitched a wonderful game against the Mount St.
Mary's nine last Wednesday, holding the visitors to a single run, as

And Andy had wonderful support.
The whole tone of the team's
playing has been raised tremendously by the acquisition of a pitcher
who can pitch, and one could not
wish to see a better brand of ball
playing than has been pulled off
during the last two games. Mt. St.
Mary's was held to three hits during the entire game.

TENNIS TEAM OPENS SEASON
WITH DEFEAT
Downed by Naval Academy Racqueters
5 to 1. Duffy Only Hopkins
Player to Win His Match.

The Tennis Team lost its first
match of the season to Navy last
Wednesday by a score of 5 to 1.
Wells, Rowland and Pickford were
all defeated in the singles competition, while Captain Duffy was the
only Hopkins racqueteer who was
able to score a victory over his
Midshipman opponent. In the doubles Pickford and Wells lost, 6-3,
6-1, while Duffy and Rowland were
defeated in a hard-contested match,
6-2, 7-5.
The matches were played on a
cold and windy day and the inclement weather had made practice for
the week previous impossible. Considering the fact that Navy always
turns out one of the, best teams in
the country, the team's showing was
far from bad, and with the aid of
a little good weather ought to be
iContinued on page 7 col. 2)

Johns Hopkins, in spite of the
fact that her squad was divided,
finished fifth in the ninth annual
Middle Atlantic- States collegiate
meet • Saturday, collecting 13 2
points., in competition with the best
athletes in the conference.
Rutgers, winner of the meet,
piled up 28 points, defeating Lafayette, her nearest rival, by 6
points.
Seven M. A. S. C. records were
broken, four in the field and three
!in the track events. The first
record to fall was the 100-yard
dash, in which Le Coney, of Lafayette, clipped- two-fifths of a second
off of the old record, which has
stood for six years, his time being
94-5 seconds.
The most thrilling race, from a
Hopkins point of view, was the
half-mile, wone by Edwards. Holding fourth position until the last
lap, he burst into a terrific sprint,
passing McPherson, of Lehigh;
Crawford, of Lafayette, and Stuart,
of Rutgers, who had set the pace.
The time, 1 minute 59 4-5 seconds,
was within 3-5 of a second of the
record. This was Hopkins only
first place.
Clark also performed admirably,
coming in a close second in the 100yard dash and third in the 220-yard
dash. Aaronson finished third in
the 220-yard low hurdles and tied
with Reinhartz, of Muhlenberg, for
fourth place in the pole vault.
Another exciting feature of the
day was the mile run, in which
Crawford, of Lafayette, and
Booth, of Delaware, tied for first.
Somerville came- in a safe third,
leaving the rest of the field some
distance back.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 17, 1921
THE HONOR SYSTEM

The Dean, in his short discussion
of the Honor System at the assembly last Thursday, brought several
facts to the fore that might be given serious attention by the students.
The most important of these without question is whether the doubts
expressed by members of the Faculty and students as to the practicability of the system are supported
by any real foundation. The Dean
himself and the Student Council
think otherwise and every Hopkins
man that has the real welfare of our
college at heart hopes that they are
right in their stand.
It certainly is to be deplored that
any suspicion of dishonesty should
be even thought of in an institution such as ours. The only way by
which talk of this character may
be stopped is to show the authors
of these stories that the condition
does not exist by holding the June
Examinations so that no shadow of
cheating can possibly be conjured
up by any person who is waiting to
grasp the vestige of an irregularity
to cry out the failure of the Honor
System.

The Debating Council, at a recent meeting, elected R.• Dorsey
Watkins, '22, president, and Lawrence B. Fenneman, '23,secretaryireasurer. Charles C. Marbury,
'22
.
; Adolphus D. Emmart, '22;
Parker C. Williams, '23, and J. E.
Mount, '24, were chosen to represent the senior, junior and sophomore classes in the Debating Council in 1921-'22.
The Council voted to award
Varsity Seals to R. Dorsey Watkins, Adolphus D. Emmart, Parker
C. Williams and Albert Dimond,
.C
the Hopkins debaters in the Triangular Debate with Washington
and Lee and the University of
North Carolina. These names will
be awarded to the Varsity Seal
Voting Council for final action.
The Council further decided that
Hopkins would insist upon the careful and judicial selection of judges
for future triangle debates. The
failure of the other universities to
select judges for their contests, as
prescribed by the general agreement, has worked disadvantageously
tc Johns Hopkins. According to
the existing agreement the judges
were to be. members of the faculty
of the university at which the debate is held. In the recent triangle
affair of April 30th, three members
of the board of judges at the University of North Carolina and only
one at Washington and Lee were
chosen according to the stipulations
of the agreement.
Incidentally the Hopkins debaters received the favorable decisions of all of these.

Hisler, of Drexel, won tremendous applause in the two-mile
run. Leading from the start, he
finished far ahead of his nearest
rival, Schmidt, of Bucknell. His
time, 9 minutes 45 seconds, broke
another record.
Betzmer, of -Delaware, in the
javelin throw, gave a wonderful exhibition of physical prowess, hurling for a distance of 172 feet 2
inches, breaking still another
record.
Despite the heavy rains of the
week, the paths were in. excellent
condition. The weather was ideal
and although the stands were but
sparsely filled for the opening of
the games, an enthusiastic crowd
witnessed the finals and the field
events.

The hall will be artistically decorated with the University and class
colors. There will be special favors for all and the suitably engraved and neatly bound souvenir
cards. It is the committee's desire
to make this the best Senior Prom
ever held at Homewood. and from
all indications their desire will be
fulfilled.
On Saturday, the 18th, there will
probably be an Alumni Smoker to
the graduates at the Hopkins Club.
This has not as yet been fully decided upon.
Sunday morning, at the 11 o'clock
service at Grace and St. Peter's,
Dr. H. P. Almon Abbott will preach
the baccalaureate sermon. The students will march in wearing their
caps and gowns, headed by the
faculty similarly attired. There will
be about 400 seats reserved in the
front of the church for the friends
of the students and the faculty.
Class Day comes on Monday-, the
20th, at 3:30 P. M. . It will take
place on the main.steps of. Gilman
Hall. The program for the afternoon will be as follows: '
L Selection- .by Undergraduate
Band.
2. Address by Chairman C. I: T.
Gould.
3. Award of athletic honors by
Dr. Abercrombie.
4. Class statistics and awards, by
C. I. T. Gould.
5. Unveiling of Sigma Chi Beta
tablet to most popular men.
6. Address by Dr. Charles
Swarts, honorary president of the
class.
7. University songs by University Quartet.
8. Presentation of 0. D. K. Cup
by Joseph C. Thompson.
9. Address by K. R. Mulliken,
president of Class of 1921.

After the completion of these exercises an informal tea dance will
be held in the C. E. Hall. The Music will probably be furnished by
the Undergraduate Orchestra.
At nine o'clock the same evening
the Senior Banquet will be held.
The managements are in the hands
of E. R. Taylor and a committee.
Ralph F. Bowers has been chosen
toastmaster for the evening. Beside Bowers the speakers will be:
Dr. Charles Swartz, "The Class
of 1921."
E. S. Wood, "Athletics."
R. G. Heiner, "Student Activities."
K. R. Mulliken, "The University."
The "Senior Week" will come to
v close on Tuesday, June 21st. The
conferring of degrees will take
place at the Lyric at four o'clock.

also be present- at tlas§ day and
other such occasions as .they: are

AN OPEN LETTER TO THE JUNIOR
AND SOPHOMORE CLASSES'.

Gentlemen:
Every activity on the campus at
Homewood welcomes publicity for
Johns Hopkins—of the right kind.
But the wrong kind of publicity is
much worse than none at all—particularly the kind that spreads by
rumor and is exaggerated as it is
passed on.- Some such undesirable
publicity, persistent and widespread, has been produced by reports of the entertainment at the
recent class banquets of the junior
and the sophomore classes. An excess of zeal on .the part of paid entertainers apparently resulted in a
type of vaudeville out of place in a
gathering of college men and distasteful to practically all of the
guests. There is one sure way to
prevent a recurrence of this sort of
thing at future class dinners and
that is a return to the tradition of
former years—class dinners at
which there are no paid entertainers. If tired business men want .to
be cheered and soothed at their
gatherings by female dancers and
monologists imported from the Gayety Theater that is their affairs;
but college men, who are living the
intellectual life ought certainly to
have wit and good fellowship
enough to make such a recourse inadequate and unnecessary. Consequently, the Omicron Delta Kappa
Society speaking, it firmly believes,
for the best public opinion on the
campus, urges upon the classes concerned the adoption for next year
of a policy that will make impossible such criticism as has been going about recently.
A Co \I MITTEE OF THE 0. D. K.
ALL HONOR OR NO HONOR?
JOHNS HOPKINS.

We must have a system either
entirely with Or without honor. If
we have the first, the student should
be given no reason to believe that
there is any doubt of his honor.
The signing of pledge slips and the
occasional supervision by "watchmen" should be entirely done away
with. Both of these are blots on
our present system and are a constant remihder of a lurking distrust
on the part of our faculty.
A man should be free to takz.•
an exam in any room that he wishes.
One of the best proofs that I
have ever seen of the efficiency of
the system occurred last year. With
six other students of the same
course, all of them average-minded
members of the student body, I left
an examination room and took the
exam, in a cooler and quieter room
away from the distracting gazes of
some fifty classmates. I can honestly say that there was not even
the least hint of help given or received in the room during the entire examination.
In adopting.a 100 per cent. honor
system we are not experimenting;
we are using a system that has been
tried and found successful in hundreds of other institutions.
For my part I shall be happy to
see the time when Hopkins joins
this progressive group and leaves
behind the elementary school tacD. M.
tics now in use.

COURSE ON INTRODUCTION TO
COLLEGE WORK TO BE GIVEN
NEXT YEAR.

According to an announcement
made last week, a novel course is
to be established at the University
next year. •
The course, which is to be known
as "Introduction to College Work,"
will be an elective for freshmen and
will be limited to 25 students.
Dr. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, who is
responsible for the establishment of
the course, will supervise the instruction, with the assistance of instructors from several of the other
departments.
It is believed that this course,
which is regarded as unique in college curricula, will serve to better
fit the entering student for his coming work.

Among the subjects covered will
be methods of study, principles of
logical reasoning, elementary statistical methods, observation of
physical fact, how scientific theory
is built up and the ideals and aims
of science.

The Omicron Delta Kappa Fraternity was founded at Washington
and Lee University in 1914, and the
Beta Circle was instituted at this
university in 1916 Its membership comprises students who have
distinguished themselves in scholarship, athletics, social leadership, including conspicuous service to the
college; literary work, including
contests, and college journalism.
Only three per cent. of the undergraduate enrollment may be elected
in any one year.
The private initiation of these
men was held Thursday evening at
the Hopkins Club. The speakers on
this occasion were Major Enoch B.
Garey, commandant of the R. 0.
T. C., and Mr. Oppenheimer, of the
